title.narrative: Promoting ecotourism to strengthen Protected Area System

description.narrative: Promoting ecotourism to strengthen the financial sustainability of the Guatemalan Protected Areas System (SIGAP)
Promoviendo el ecoturismo para fortalecer la sostenibilidad financiera del Sistema Guatemalteco de Áreas Protegidas (SIGAP)
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

To strengthen the financial sustainability of Guatemalaâ€™s Protected Areas System (SIGAP) by developing new financing vehicles within the developing ecotourism sector, while ensuring the alignment of ecotourism activities with biodiversity conservation objectives.

1.- Number of tourism routes within five pilot Western Highlands landscapes (i.e., RUMCLA - Lake Atitlan, Todos Santos Cuchumatan, Tacana Volcano, Tajumulco Volcano, and Chicabal Lagoon-Volcano) contribute to the conservation of 152,146 hectares (ha) with biodiversity of global importance.

comment.narrative: Five (5)
Seven (7)

The project is reviewing the 5 routs designed by Helvetas in oreder to ensure a good synergy with the Bussiness Plans currently under construction. Those routes are:
- Ruta Puerta al Altiplano
- Ruta Toto-K ´iche
- Ruta Valle Central
- Ruta Boca-Costa

description.narrative: 2.- Total area (hectares [ha]) protected by PAs in the Western Highlands with ecotourism benefits.

comment.narrative: 7,255.4 ha (MRP Todos Santos Cuchumatan).

Total hectares protected in Western Highlands with ecotourism benefits: 10,500.95 This represent an achievement of 73% Notice that from that total: - 9,317.74 are part of the 7 pilot areas of the project
- 2,183.21 are other protected areas in the Western Highlands not included as pilot area. The pilot areas with ecotourism benefits are: - Municipal Regional Park Todos Santos Cuchumatan
- Municipal Regional Park Sibinal (Canjula, Tocapote, los Maijones and Tacana)
- Permanent Ban Area Volcan Chicabal
- Corazon del Bosque
The project does not directly collaborate with the administrators of areas not included in the group of 7 pilot areas. However it fosters tourism development at regional level through caring out activities of promotion and strengthening CONAP Offices' capacities. These actions positively boost income generation from tourism, not only the 7 pilot areas, but at regional level. Due to the characteristics and location of the pilot areas, a regional strategy is crucial. The pilot areas must be linked to other tourism destinations and attractions. Examples of how the project promotes this strategy are a) the design of tourism routes and b) a press tour which promoted protected areas in the region of San Marcos. The 2,183.21 hectares not included in the project correspond to the following protected areas: - Vieja Catarina
- Yul Ha Saj Ha´
- El Baul
- Concepcion Chiquirichapa
- Cerro Mano de León (Cerro Sija)
- Finca Patrocinio
- Finca Comunitaria Magnolia Miramar
- Finca Comunitaria Loma Linda
- Astillero Municipal San Cristobal Cucho IMPORTANT NOTE: The hectarage of three pilot areas have been modified during the lifetime of the project. Thus, the current size of the areas have been reduced and do not coincided with the hectares recorded in prodoc. This will affect to the "target level at the end of the project". Following are explained the modifications: - Volcan Chicabal: Have change from the 1,572 ha. recorder in prodoc to 496 ha. Changed through CONAP's resolution 01-08-2014 (June 2014), based on the study "LOS VOLCANES DE GUATEMALA: IDENTIFICACION Y PRIORIZACION PARA SU MANEJO DENTRO DE LA ESTRATEGIA DE DESARROLLO DEL SISTEMA NACIONAL DE AREAS PROTEGIDAS",
- Rey Tepepul: Form 3,892 ha. recorder in prodoc to 3509.91. This area has not been declared yet. The 3509.91 are the hectares proposed by the project to be register in order to resolve challenges regarding land tenure.
- Corazon del Bosque: From 35.4 ha. to 8.94 ha. This area has not been declared yet. The 8.94 are the hectares proposed by the project to be register in order to resolve challenges regarding uncertainty of land tenure.

description.narrative: Strengthened legal and policy framework for implementing ecotourism as part of a strategy to engender the financial sustainability of the SIGAP.
5.- Change in the legal and policy framework at the national level.

comment.narrative: 1) Policy for Tourism Activities in PAs 2) Co-administration policy in PAs 3) CONAP regulation for control and reinvestment of income from PAs 4) Regulation of Concession Services for Visitors in SIGAP

1) Policy for Tourism Activities in PAs reformed 2) Co-administration policy in PAs reformed 3) CONAP regulation for control and reinvestment of income from PAs updated 4) Regulation of Concession Services for Visitors in SIGAP updated 5) Regulatory guidelines for environmental standards and certification system for ecotourism in PAs developed.

1) 100% achieved. Policy for Tourism Activities in PAs reformed. 2) 100% achieved. Co-administration Policy in PAs reformed and re-named as Policy of shared management and joint administration. 3) 80% achieved. First draft of CONAP regulation for control and reinvestment of income from PAs elaborated and currently under revision. This draft addresses both, the income regulation and visitor entering management. NOTE: Followiong the 2014-PIR note, due to the importance of not only regulate the entry of visitors but also the income, finally the project will promote the update of the regulation for control and reinvestment of income. 5) 90% achieved: Regulatory guidelines for environmental standards and certification system for ecotourism designed. The strategy for implementing the certification system was stablished and the first pilot assessment was undertaken jointly with the Guatemala’s National Tourism Institute (INGUAT) and the Ministry of Culture and Sport (MICUDE). More information about this achievement can be found in the Implementation Progress Section of this report. 6) Furthermore, the following management tools were designed and approved: -Tourism in Protected Areas Potential Assessment Tool
- Guide for the Elaboration of Public Use Plans
- Committee for Tourism in Protected Areas (COTURAP) internal regulation was reformed

description.narrative: 6.- Number of PAs implementing Public Use Plans (indicator for reformed Policy on Tourist Activities in PAs)

comment.narrative: Four (4)
Eleven (11)

Overall Achievement: 65% Progress in the design and approval of Public Use Plan: 1. Municipal Regional Park Astillero Municipal de San Marcos: 100% designed. Currently pending approval. 2. Municipal Regional Park Astillero Municipal I y II de San Pedro Sacatepéquez: 100% designed, Currently pending approval. 3. Municipal Regional Park Canjula, Tocapote, Los Maijones (Sibinal): 100% designed, Currently pending approval. 4. Municipal Regional Park Todos Santos Cuchumatan: 30% designed. 5. Permanent Ban Area Volcán de Chicabal: 0% designed. Consultant hired and works have already begun. 6. Corazon del Bosque: 0% designed. 7. Municipal Regional Park for Mirador Rey Tepepul: 100% designed but not yet submitted for approval. To achieve the approval of the Public Use Plan, it is previously necessary to achieve the registration of the area in the Guatemalan System of Protected Areas –SIGAP-. Although the project has supported the Municipality to resolve the problems faced about land tenure that historically did not allow the registration of the area, has not yet been included. Please find more information on this issue in the Development Objective Rating section of this report. In addition, previous the design of Public Use Plans, it is necessary to design the Management Plan, which regulates the overall management of the protected area. The project is designing the Management Plan for the 7 pilot protected areas. Progress in the design and approval of Management Plans: 1. Municipal Regional Park Astillero Municipal de San Marcos: 100% designed and approved. 2. Municipal Regional Park Astillero Municipal I y II de San Pedro Sacatepéquez: 100% designed. Currently pending approval. 3. Municipal Regional Park Canjula, Tocapote, Los Maijones (Sibinal): 100% designed. Currently pending approval. 4. Municipal Regional Park Todos Santos Cuchumatan:100% designed and approved. 5. Permanent Ban Area Volcan de Chicabal: 0% designed. 6. Corazon del Bosque: 60% designed. The activity has suffered repeated delays due to uncertainty over land tenure and administrator's internal organization problems. The land tenure uncertainty has been clarified and the project is currently supporting the community based organization which administrates de area in order to resolve internal organization challenges. 7. Municipal Regional Park for Mirador Rey Tepepul: 100% designed but not yet submitted for approval. Same situation than with the Public Use Plan.

Institutions in the Capital (headquarters): 0 Some of the activities carried out in order to achieve the target of this indicator are: 1) The implementation of the capacity building programme for protected areas' administrators. The programme benefited a total, 124 people. The external evaluation concluded the following: "The program fulfilled its objective of increasing the technical capabilities of managers of protected areas, within both CONAP and its external partners. On the basis of these results, it can be concluded that giving full support to this training program will result in the improvement of the skills of CONAP technicians oriented towards the management of tourism in protected areas, thus contributing to the financial sustainability of the areas in accordance with the goal of preserving the biodiversity." 2) The launch of the "Diploma of Identification, Formulation, Evaluation and Presentation of Sustainable Touristic Projects" jointly organized by CONAP, INGUAT, the National Institute of Public Administration (INAP), the Secretariat of Planning and Programming of the Presidency (SEGEPLAN) and the National Agency for Public Private Partnership for the Development of Economic Infrastructure ( ANADIE). This 80 hour-course addressed to 30 public servants and seeks to train staff for the formulation of projects of touristic development in protected areas, from a perspective of sustainability, conservation and economic use. Especially relevant is the joint participation of several governmental institutions with the private sector, all which boost tourism as a crosscutting sector, whose development requires both a governmental strategy and a proper synergy with the private sector. 3) The implementation of the second edition of the training programme for CONAP Officials, which was carried out benefiting to 45 people (10 women and 35 men)

description.narrative: 10.- Number of PAs in the Western Highlands established and registered in SIGAP

comment.narrative: Thirty-nine (39)
Forty-one (41)

Forty-three (43) Baseline + 4 Achievement: 200% The following protected areas were registered during the current reporting period: - Municipal Regional Park San Rafael Pie de la Cuesta, San Marcos (41.3 hectares)
- Municipal Regional Pack Piedras de Kab'tzin, Huehuetenango (304.3 hectares)
- Private Natural Reserve Monte de Oro (915.54 hectares) The project has not directly taken action in order to the registration of these areas. However the activities aimed at strengthening the capacity of the CONAP's Regional Offices and in the deffinition of CONAP's internal processes, have positive effects in the promotion of new protected areas and in the promotion of tourism as a potential contributor to financial sustainability. The project financed a press tour to San Rafael Pie de la Cuesta in order to promote birdwatching tourism in this area where Quetzals are visible. This will greatly benefit the pilot areas in the proximities due to the attraction to visitors to the region. In addition, the project is still supporting the registration of Rey Tepepul and Corazón del Bosque, two of the pilot areas of the project, which have presented historical problems related to the uncertainty of land tenure and internal organization. More information about this situation can be found in the Development Objective Rating Section of this report

description.narrative: 11.- Number of PAs in the Western Highlands with monitoring, evaluation, and mitigation programs addressing impacts of ecotourism on ecologically sensitive areas

comment.narrative: Zero (0)
Seven (7)

90% achieved The monitoring program was designed and implemented in the 7 pilot areas. Furthermore it includes a training program for municipality workers and CONAP´s regional officers in order to stablish the program in a ssutainable manner once the project hav fiished. From this first pilot experience lessons have been learnt and adjustments will be undertaken in following editions. For this reason the achievement is considered 90% and not 100% although the seven areas already implement the monitoring, evaluation and mitigation program.

description.narrative: 13.- Number of PAs in the Western Highlands with a system of entrance fees and visitor services in operation

comment.narrative: Two (2): PBA Volcan and Laguna de Chicabal, and MRP Concepcion Chiquirichapa
Eight (8): Baseline + 6 pilot areas

The total number of PAs with entrance fees in Western Highlands is 10. This represents an achievement of 125%. Notice that from that total: 3 areas are part of the 7 pilot areas of the project
- Ban Area Volcan and Laguna Chicabal
- Corazon del Bosque
- Municipal Regional Park Canjula, Tocapote, Los Maijones are still operating 7 areas are other PAs in the Western Highlands which are not included as pilot area.
- Concepción Chiquirichapa (included in the baseline)
- Yul Ha Saj Ha´
- El Baul
- Cerro Mano de Leon (Cerro Sija)
- The entrance fee systems are currently operating in
- Astillero Municipal San Cristobal Cucho
- Refugio del Quetzal, San Rafael Pie de la cuesta, Volcan Tajumulco In addition, in the Regional Park Todos Santos Cuchumatan, entrance fees are operating by 4 community-based tourism commissions. These groups are currently managing the tourism activity in the park but with a legal agreement with the Municipality, the legally stablished administrator of the area. For the four pilot areas that have not implemented entrance fees yet: the project assisted in their calculation. Local governments received received the proposal as a very positive tool to increase income from tourism. However, local authorities stated that the upcoming elections do not provide a favourable political situation to implement these kind of measures. The efforts in this direction will continue after the election period, when new new authorities have been elected. As explained in other indicators, the project have not directly taken actions in order to implement entrance fees in areas out of the 7 pilot areas. However, the Capacity building programmes for CONAP's Regional Offices, and the promotion of tourism as financial tool for protected areas have positive effects also in other areas not included in those 7.

description.narrative: 2. Area (ha) (by forest type) under best management practices in LULUCF*, including monitoring of C stocks (CCM-5) *Conserve and enhance carbon stocks in selected forested areas.

comment.narrative:
? Dry forest: 620.1 ha

* Dry forest: 2000 ha. This was achieve with the joint work of the project with the Forest National Institute (INAB) as part the ongoing process to promote national incentives under the PINPEP modality.
* Humid forest: 50 ha. This was achieve with the work of FUNDAECO with the support of the project and in close collaboration and participation of the local communities and the National Forest Institute (INAB) as well as the support of the local authorities. The annual goal was not met due to two factors, the first is that the natural regeneration for this ecosystem is slow and takes more time. And secondly, for the lack of resources (economic and plants) to promote the natural regeneration and rehabilitation of the forest.
The expected target for 2015 was to have a first trial of the methods in the monitoring of C stocks, but this methodology still is under construction, as part of the REDD+ National Strategy.

description.narrative: Regulatory and institutional framework integrates principles of sustainable forest management (SFM) and sustainable land management (SLM), and strengthens integrated environmental land management capacity.
6. National policies incorporate SLM and SFM considerations

comment.narrative:
? Forest incentives program for small landowners
? Law for the Protection and Improvement of the Environment
? Forestry Policy

? National Action Program to Combat Desertification and Drought (PROANDYS) updated
? Agricultural Policy of Guatemala reformed

* PROBOSQUE draft bill has been submitted to Congress. PROBOSQUE is a new draft bill that aims to replace the almost finished Program de Incentivos Forestales (PINFOR) program as well as to create a better system to incentivize the forest management and also, incorporates new forest ecosystems, that were not recognized in the past, subject to receive incentives. Altogether, the PORBOSQUE is using the forest as a basis to promote sustainable development in rural areas.
* For 2015 the target was to have a Policy on Land Degradation and the PROANDYS updated. At present, there is an update on all the biophysical and political information related to land degradation, desertification and drought. Also, the objective, strategic lines and principles are already drafted and accepted. The strategic plan with actions is under consultation as well as the actualization process of the PROANDYS.

description.narrative: 7. Number of national agencies working with inter-agency agreements that integrate principles of SFM and SLM.

comment.narrative: 5: MARN, MAGA, INAB, CONAP, and ANAM

* 4 agencies(Forest National Institute (INAB), Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Food (MAGA), Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (MARN), National Council of Protected Areas (CONAP) and General Secretariat of Planning (SEGEPLAN)) includes principles of SLM and SFM in their policies, by having a common understanding of the concepts on SLM, SFM, climate change and Sustainable Use of Biodiversity. This was achieved by having consultation with legal representatives from the 4 agencies.

This support to CONAP will also include its dissemination with key local actors and guidelines to its effective implementation. Note: A change of the indicator regarding the Law of Fishing and Aquaculture is requested with the support of the Technical Committee, aiming to a more viable initiative. The San José Canyon has been recognized by the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) as an Ecologically or Biologically Significant Marine Area (EBSA). Through a ministerial agreement it can be established as a ban area and/or breeding area of key species, particularly white shark and sailfish.

One area of biological importance already declared by CBD and regulated by Ministerial decree (i.e., Cañon de San Jose).

This is a new indicator. The Cañon de San Jose biological area will be regulated by ministerial decree in 2016. The San José Canyon has been recognized by the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) as an Ecologically or Biologically Significant Marine Area (EBSA). The ministerial decree is needed to regulate the use white shark and sailfish, amongst other key species.

In May 2015 coordination started with DIPESCA-MAGA regarding monitoring and control. Several technical meetings and one workshop have resulted in consensus among staff from DIPESCA-MAGA (3), CONAP (1), INAB (1) and Ocean and Aquaculture Research Center CEMA-USAC (1) for monitoring formats that include threats to mangroves, fisheries and sea turtles.
Progress of this target will be measure by mid-2017, before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2017

One joint work plan (including methodology and timeframe) between DIPESCA-MAGA, CONAP and INAB has been built and from July to December it is expected to accomplish 5 patrolling events (1 x 5 MPA). A monitoring program per MPA will be agreed as part of the Management Plans to be elaborated in 2016.

comment.narrative:

? Herbaceous wetlands: 8,138 ha

In order to maintain current levels of conservation and sustainable use of marine-coastal biodiversity, two initiatives requested by CONAP have been supported. Regulations for Whale Watching were published in the official gazette and the Hunting Calendar for the South Coast has been updated.
Progress of this target will be measure by mid-2017, before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2017

description.narrative: 12. Number of nurseries certified by CONAP for their good practices and compliance with the official Guidelines of the National Strategy for Sea Turtle Conservation in Guatemala.

comment.narrative: 0 nurseries

Three (3) nurseries to be certified by CONAP: 1. Monterrico-CECON (Center for Conservation Studies)2. Hawaii-ARCAS (Wildlife Rescue and Conservation Association) 3. Sipacate-ICC (Private Institute for Climate Change)

This is a new indicator.
A revision of the National Strategy for Sea Turtle Conservation in Guatemala was requested by CONAP. It was noticed that the Guidelines for release of sea turtle hatchlings are not being implemented satisfactory in the Pacific nurseries. This is why the nurseries need to be certified.

description.narrative: 13. Minimum sizes (cm) of select fish species in four (4) multiple-use MPAs and their buffer zones in conformance with FAO regulations[1] [1] The regulation proposed by the FAO is aimed at the minimum sizes; in the case of fisheries maximum sizes are not considered, since the concern with the stocks of fish is that the organisms reach at least their initial reproduction size, which allows them to maintain stable populations. For other species there are no regulations regarding sizes.

comment.narrative:
Commercially important species:
? White Shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei)
? Blue Shrimp (Penaeus stylirostris)
? Brown Shrimp (Farfantepenaeus.
californiensis)
? Hammerhead Shark (Sphyrna lewini)

Commercially important species:
? White Shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei): 3 g or 6.6 cm.
? Blue Shrimp (Penaeus stylirostris): 3 g or 6.6 cm.
? Brown Shrimp (Farfantepenaeus californiensis): 3 g or 6.6 cm.
? Hammerhead Shark (Sphyrna lewini): 220 cm total length for females and 178 cm for males.

Two initiatives leaded by DIPESCA-MAGA and CONAP focused on sharks (including Hammerhead Shark) and manta rays conservation started this year.
The first one is the characterization and assessment of state and the second one is a marketing chain and traceability system for these species. Both processes will support the country to accomplish acquired compromises as a CITES Contracting Party. Compliance with the regulations of the General Law of Fishing and Aquaculture favors stable catches and sizes of four (4) selected fishing species.
Baseline: use of 600 meters gillnet, mesh size of ½ inches and 8 simultaneous gill nets (illegal fishing gear)
Target: use of 100 meters gillnet, 2.5 inches mesh size and 3 gillnets maximum (Article 50, Literal H of the normative of the General Law of Fishing and Aquaculture) contributes to sustainable use of:
1. Snapper (Lutjanus sp)
2. Yellowfin Snook (Centropomus robalito)
3. Mackerel (Scomberomorus sierra)
4. White Shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei)
